Let G : \mathcal { D } \to \mathcal { C } be a functor with a left adjoint F. M = G \circ F is the corresponding monad on \mathcal { C }. This gives a comparison functor K : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { C } ^M.

fr:ol.fr:li: If \mathcal { D } has all coequalizers (we can weaken this to reflexive coequalizers), then K has a left adjoint.
If moreover G preserves these reflexive coequalizers, the unit \textrm {Id} \to K \circ L is an isomorphism.
Finally, if G reflects isomorphisms, then the counit L \circ K \to \textrm {Id} is also an isomorphism, making G monadic.
